repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
As described in https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.10.html#parenthesized-context-managers

The approach to parsing is largely copied from the CPython parser
(with comments to support it) - closer to the PEG approach of
"try the bracketed case first, and let it fail silently then
try the unbracketed case".

Fixes one of the items listed in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4595

comment_data.body: An alternative approach (which might/might not be better) would be to create the nodes with an empty body, then fill in the body in the `p_with_items` loop. It might be a little more readable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2130,24 +2177,14 @@ def p_with_items(s, is_async=False):
             condition = p_test(s)
             s.expect(')')
 
-        if s.sy == ',':
-            s.next()
-            body = p_with_items(s)
-        else:
-            body = p_suite(s)
-        return Nodes.GILStatNode(pos, state=state, body=body, condition=condition)
+        return "gil", pos, state, condition
     else:
         manager = p_test(s)
         target = None
         if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'as':
             s.next()
             target = p_starred_expr(s)
-        if s.sy == ',':
-            s.next()
-            body = p_with_items(s, is_async=is_async)
-        else:
-            body = p_suite(s)
-    return Nodes.WithStatNode(pos, manager=manager, target=target, body=body, is_async=is_async)
+    return "with", pos, manager, target

comment_data.body: Hmm. This file is copied from CPython's test suite and I usually try to avoid larger changes in order to simplify later updates by overwriting the file and keeping some changes. OTOH, it's definitely expensive to fire up the whole compiler for a bunch of simple snippets like this, so, well, I guess it's worth changing into plain code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1869,68 +1868,53 @@ def __exit__(self, *args):
         with manager() as x, manager():
             pass
 
-        if not use_old_parser():

comment_data.body: It's certainly unusual to return anything but a node from a `p_*` parser function. I wouldn't mind setting the `body` after the fact. Seems simple and reasonable here.

comment_data.body: My changes match the current version in CPython's test suite anyway so I don't think they'll make it harder to update in future: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/16b6e14cc291865ecaf50fa57d0685da94496567/Lib/test/test_grammar.py#L1819
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1869,68 +1868,53 @@ def __exit__(self, *args):
         with manager() as x, manager():
             pass
 
-        if not use_old_parser():

comment_data.body:
It turns out that there's quite a bit of logic in the constructor of `GilStatNode` that means that you have to know what `body` is when you construct it and can't set it later.

I've therefore gone back to something closer to what I had before where the construction of the nodes is delay. Although hopefully it's a little neater now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2130,24 +2177,14 @@ def p_with_items(s, is_async=False):

-        return Nodes.GILStatNode(pos, state=state, body=body, condition=condition)
+        return "gil", pos, state, condition
     else:
         manager = p_test(s)
         target = None
         if s.sy == 'IDENT' and s.systring == 'as':
             s.next()
             target = p_starred_expr(s)
-        if s.sy == ',':

-            body = p_with_items(s, is_async=is_async)
-        else:
-            body = p_suite(s)
-    return Nodes.WithStatNode(pos, manager=manager, target=target, body=body, is_async=is_async)
+    return "with", pos, manager, target

comment_data.body: Ah, ok, so they changed that as well (thus fully committing to the new parser). Then that's perfect.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1869,68 +1868,53 @@ def __exit__(self, *args):
         with manager() as x, manager():
             pass
 
-        if not use_old_parser():

comment_data.body: Do we really need to parse twice here? Can't we just expect a closing parenthesis if there was an opening one, and in between just collect comma separated expressions?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2144,6 +2144,52 @@ def p_with_statement(s):
 
 
 def p_with_items(s, is_async=False):
+    """
+    Copied from CPython:
+    | 'with' '(' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ','? ')' ':' b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NULL, EXTRA) }
+    | 'with' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ':' tc=[TYPE_COMMENT] b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NEW_TYPE_COMMENT(p, tc), EXTRA) }
+    Therefore the first thing to try is the bracket-enclosed
+    version and if that fails try the regular version
+    """
+    brackets_succeeded=False
+    if s.sy == '(':
+        items = []
+        with tentatively_scan(s) as errors:
+            s.next()
+            while True:
+                items.append(p_with_item(s, is_async))
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+                s.expect(",")
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    # trailing commas allowed
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+        brackets_succeeded = not errors
+    if not brackets_succeeded:

comment_data.body:
I think the difficulty is (and why it didn't work in the LL parser)

```
with (a+b), c:
```

It becomes really difficult to tell if the brackets are part of the first expression, or if they're around the whole thing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: Although – hang on, that's what we did before (without the parentheses). What was wrong with that again?

comment_data.body:
It doesn't support

```
with (cm1 as a, cm2):
```

So it'd assume that any bracket had to be enclosing an expression, and fail because the brackets were still open when it got to `as`.

Also
```
with (a, b, c):
```

Is pretty ambiguous... It's either 3 context managers or a single with statement with a tuple as a context manager. In the new grammar it ends up as 3 context managers because that's what succeeds first, but you don't know which one it'll be as you parse it
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2144,6 +2144,52 @@ def p_with_statement(s):
 
 
 def p_with_items(s, is_async=False):
+    """
+    Copied from CPython:
+    | 'with' '(' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ','? ')' ':' b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NULL, EXTRA) }
+    | 'with' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ':' tc=[TYPE_COMMENT] b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NEW_TYPE_COMMENT(p, tc), EXTRA) }
+    Therefore the first thing to try is the bracket-enclosed
+    version and if that fails try the regular version
+    """
+    brackets_succeeded=False
+    if s.sy == '(':
+        items = []
+        with tentatively_scan(s) as errors:
+            s.next()
+            while True:
+                items.append(p_with_item(s, is_async))
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+                s.expect(",")
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    # trailing commas allowed
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+        brackets_succeeded = not errors
+    if not brackets_succeeded:

comment_data.body:
> I think the difficulty is (and why it didn't work in the LL parser)
> 
> ```
> with (a+b), c:
> ```
> 
> It becomes really difficult to tell if the brackets are part of the first expression, or if they're around the whole thing.

Yes, it's not a simple LL grammar thing. However, we have a hand-written parser, not a generated one, so isn't that just
1) find parenthesis or not, set a flag
2) parse CM expression sequence (at least one)
3)
    a) if closing parenthesis is not found and flag is not set: parse suite
    b) if closing parenthesis found != flag: error
    c) if closing parenthesis is found and flag is set:
        * if there was no comma yet, discard the parentheses and allow more CMs afterwards (you can't have `(a,b,c)` or `(a,)` as valid CM expressions)
        * if there was a comma, require suite
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2144,6 +2144,52 @@ def p_with_statement(s):
 
 
 def p_with_items(s, is_async=False):
+    """
+    Copied from CPython:
+    | 'with' '(' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ','? ')' ':' b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NULL, EXTRA) }
+    | 'with' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ':' tc=[TYPE_COMMENT] b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NEW_TYPE_COMMENT(p, tc), EXTRA) }
+    Therefore the first thing to try is the bracket-enclosed
+    version and if that fails try the regular version
+    """
+    brackets_succeeded=False
+    if s.sy == '(':
+        items = []
+        with tentatively_scan(s) as errors:
+            s.next()
+            while True:
+                items.append(p_with_item(s, is_async))
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+                s.expect(",")
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    # trailing commas allowed
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+        brackets_succeeded = not errors
+    if not brackets_succeeded:

comment_data.body:
An opening bracket doesn't necessarily enclose the first CM expression: `with (a+b).func(), c:`

So in stage 2 of your scheme it isn't clear if you need to include the bracket when parsing the first CM expression. In this case you must include the opening bracket or the parsing fails. But in the case of `with (a as x):` it'd be wrong to parse the bracket as part of the first CM expression.

> (you can't have (a,b,c) or (a,) as valid CM expressions)

They're grammatically OK. They'll fail at runtime because a tuple doesn't have `__enter__` and `__exit__`.

------------------------------

The main thing to be said for the way I've done it is that it is how the current version of the Python grammar works... it tries to parse the bracket-enclosed version and if that fails tries to parse the non-bracket enclosed version. So although parsing twice is inefficient when you have to do it, it's fairly easily linked back to the Python grammar.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2144,6 +2144,52 @@ def p_with_statement(s):

+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NULL, EXTRA) }
+    | 'with' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ':' tc=[TYPE_COMMENT] b=block {
+        _PyAST_With(a, b, NEW_TYPE_COMMENT(p, tc), EXTRA) }
+    Therefore the first thing to try is the bracket-enclosed
+    version and if that fails try the regular version
+    """
+    brackets_succeeded=False
+    if s.sy == '(':
+        items = []
+        with tentatively_scan(s) as errors:
+            s.next()
+            while True:
+                items.append(p_with_item(s, is_async))
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+                s.expect(",")
+                if s.sy == ")":
+                    # trailing commas allowed
+                    s.next()
+                    break
+        brackets_succeeded = not errors
+    if not brackets_succeeded:

comment_data.body: Ok. I understand that we'd probably always find enough examples to break any other scheme than trial and error.

+    | 'with' a[asdl_withitem_seq*]=','.with_item+ ':' tc=[TYPE_COMMENT] b=block {

commit.message:
Enable parenthesized context managers

As described in https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.10.html#parenthesized-context-managers

The approach to parsing is largely copied from the CPython parser
(with comments to support it) - closer to the PEG approach of
"try the bracketed case first, and let it fail silently then
try the unbracketed case".
Refactor to return nodes and populate bodies later
Moved some parts of GILStatNode constructor after body is set
Go back to constructing later, when body is known

title: Enable parenthesized context managers
